news_summary: Innovative approaches are advancing environmental protection, from creative upcycling projects to trained dogs effectively detecting invasive insects. Scientific breakthroughs, such as studying ancient ice and exploring AI's role in conservation, are unlocking new ways to understand and safeguard nature. Additionally, research into unique wildlife adaptations, like the giant wingspans of the world’s largest bats, deepens our appreciation of biodiversity.
news_summary_fr: Des approches innovantes font progresser la protection de l'environnement, qu'il s'agisse de projets créatifs de recyclage ou de chiens dressés pour détecter efficacement les insectes envahissants. Les percées scientifiques, telles que l'étude des glaces anciennes et l'exploration du rôle de l'IA dans la conservation, ouvrent de nouvelles voies pour comprendre et sauvegarder la nature. En outre, la recherche sur les adaptations uniques de la faune, comme l'envergure des plus grandes chauves-souris du monde, nous permet d'approfondir notre appréciation de la biodiversité.
news_summary_es: La protección del medio ambiente avanza gracias a planteamientos innovadores, desde proyectos creativos de reciclaje hasta perros adiestrados para detectar insectos invasores. Los avances científicos, como el estudio del hielo milenario y la exploración del papel de la inteligencia artificial en la conservación, están abriendo nuevas vías para comprender y salvaguardar la naturaleza. Además, la investigación sobre adaptaciones únicas de la fauna, como la envergadura de los murciélagos más grandes del mundo, nos permite apreciar mejor la biodiversidad.

articles.title: 7 Ingenious Upcycling Ideas You’ll Fall in Love With!
articles.summary:
There are so many amazing people in this world who have dedicated their lives to...
The post 7 Ingenious Upcycling Ideas You’ll Fall in Love With! appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
There are so many amazing people in this world who have dedicated their lives to reducing waste and creating a better world for all of us to enjoy. Here are seven ways you can contribute, support, or get involved by turning something old into something new. We have a feeling you’ll just love these upcycling ideas!

1. Upcycle sails into seasonal decor

Sea Bags has breathed new life to over 500 tons of sails that would have otherwise gone to a landfill. Sea Bags creates fun, functional, and stylish totes, bags, wine bags, and home goods from reclaimed sailcloth in Portland, Maine. Meticulously designed and produced by Maine craftspeople, the bags are “as rugged as they come and each one is a little different than the next.”

If you’re a seaman (or woman), you can become Sail Trade Partner. You’ll earn a free Sea Bag product as thanks, or you can turn your trade into a donation to teach a child to sail. Sea Bags will even arrange to pick up the sail or pay to have it shipped to them.

2. Upcycle juice boxes into kids crafts

Feed your kids a snack, then create upcycled craft projects with them using the leftover pouches and boxes. Juicy Juice is made with 100% juice and contains no high fructose corn syrup, no cane sugar, and no artificial sweeteners. You’ll feel better about your kiddos sipping on something healthy, get your creative juices flowing and avoid creating waste.

Splashers Pencil Pouch : Why waste money on new back-to-school pencil pouches? Spend time with your kid while making a craft they’ll be proud of.

Why waste money on new back-to-school pencil pouches? Spend time with your kid while making a craft they’ll be proud of. Upcycled Juice Box Seed Starters : This is a clever way to give your kids’ favorite juice boxes a second life. Get endlessly creative in how you decorate these seed starters, and watch new life appear on your windowsill or in your backyard.

This is a clever way to give your kids’ favorite juice boxes a second life. Get endlessly creative in how you decorate these seed starters, and watch new life appear on your windowsill or in your backyard. Juicy Juice Piggy Bank: Don’t waste money on toy store piggy banks; instead, make your own by using supplies you can find in your craft drawer and an empty bottle. Not only are these absolutely adorable, but piggy banks are also a fun and simple way to get kids counting, adding, and subtracting on their own.

3. Upcycle your TV cable into an HDTV antenna

A TV industry first, ReLeaf by Mohu is an over-the-air antenna made from discarded cable set-top boxes and post-consumer recycled cardboard. In fact, one pound of plastic from cable set-top boxes can make parts for 40 Mohu TV antennas. Kudos to Mohu for literally repurposing cable’s garbage.

4. Upcycle a pizza box into plates and storage

GreenBox is truly the 100% recycled and recyclable “Swiss Army knife of pizza boxes.” Multifunctionalbecause it transforms into four plates and a compact storage unit for leftovers—and eco-conscious, the GreenBox completely eliminates the need for wasteful storage materials like paper plates, plastic wrap, aluminum foil, and more. Eat pizza, save trees and water, and reduce pollution. Now that’s appetizing!

5. Upcycle your old makeup into cash

Girls, I know you have old, unused makeup stashed in your bathroom drawers. Let’s face it, we all possess a little makeup hoarding shame. Whether you were swayed by an over complimentary salesperson or splurged on that perfect color for one night, cosmetic waste is real. But, now you can actually sell your new or pre-owned makeup products and makeup tools (i.e., brushes and palettes).

Glambot is here to help upcycle your old makeup — and they even pay for shipping. Your unused or lightly used makeup must be

Non-expired,

Have at least 50% original product remaining

Be free from contaminants (i.e., dirt, mold, pet hair)

Have labeling attached to product

And the exterior packaging cannot be not cracked, damaged, or too worn

Get a full program run down, including the full list of accepted brands.

6. Upcycle jeans into home insulation

At some point, even the most comfortable of denim gets too worn or no longer fits. But why throw away good material when it can be turned into (healthy) home insulation? Yes, you read that right. After you send your jeans to the ingenious peeps at Blue Jeans Go Green, it’s upcycled into UltraTouch Denim Insulation made from 80% post-consumer recycled denim. They accept jackets, skirts, and shirts.

This denim insulation is not only environmentally friendly, it’s not carcinogenic, contains no formaldehyde or chemical irritants, offers extraordinary thermal performance, and provides 30% better sound absorption than traditional fiberglass insulation. Goodbye pink, hello blue.

The giving-back-buck doesn’t stop there. Many retail partners offer a discount on new jeans when you return your old pair. Plus, you can apply to receive insulation for your local community, be it a Habitat for Humanity project or even a civic building. Bonded Logic, Inc., the manufacturer of UltraTouch has donated to over 30 Habitat for Humanity affiliates around the country and provided insulation to Hurricane Katrina victims.

7. Upcycle your furniture to benefit veterans

The great people at Furnishing Hope in Santa Ana, California, have created a program that rewards wounded heroes while keeping unused furniture and décor items out of the landfill. Tired of witnessing thousands of dollars worth of furniture being disposed of from high-end clients, Furnishing Hope was created by Beth Phillips, a former interior designer. Beth sought a way to bring together people in need with those who have more than enough.

Today, the nonprofit works with a network of designers and volunteers who transform home environments. By partnering with the U.S. military’s Family Readiness Officers, they offer veterans in crisis the opportunity to experience the transformation of an empty house into a nurturing and comfortable home. You too can get involved by donating new or gently used furniture or your time, adopting a family, or making a tax-deductible donation.

No act is too small.

“Never underestimate the power of a small group of people to change the world. In fact, it is the only way it ever has.” –Margaret Mead

Editor’s Note: Originally published on September 9, 2016, this article was updated in July 2025. Feature image credit: Sea Bags.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights multiple creative and impactful upcycling initiatives that reduce waste, promote sustainability, and support communities, which aligns with environmental progress and positive social impact.
articles.personality_title: 7 creative ways to turn old items into something wonderful
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many people around the world are working hard to reduce waste and protect our planet. Upcycling is one way to do this—it means taking old or unused things and transforming them into new, useful, or beautiful items.

**What happened**
A recent collection of seven brilliant upcycling ideas has been shared to inspire everyone. For example, Sea Bags has turned over 500 tons of old sails into stylish seasonal decorations, proving that what was once trash can become treasure.

**Impact**
These creative projects not only keep tons of waste out of landfills but also promote sustainability and support communities. They show how small changes can make a big difference for the environment and people alike.

**What's next step**
You can get involved by trying out one of these upcycling ideas yourself, supporting businesses that focus on upcycling, or spreading the word about this positive movement. Every effort counts!

**One-sentence takeaway**
Turning old things into new treasures is a fun, impactful way to help our planet and inspire others.
articles.personality_title_fr: 7 façons créatives de transformer les anciens articles en quelque chose de merveilleux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
De nombreuses personnes dans le monde travaillent dur pour réduire les déchets et protéger notre planète. L'UPCycling est une façon de le faire - cela signifie prendre des choses anciennes ou inutilisées et les transformer en articles nouveaux, utiles ou beaux.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une récente collection de sept idées d'upcycling brillantes a été partagée pour inspirer tout le monde. Par exemple, Sea Bags a transformé 500 tonnes de vieilles voiles dans des décorations de saison élégantes, prouvant que ce qui était autrefois des ordures peut devenir un trésor.

**Impact**
Ces projets créatifs empêchent non seulement des tonnes de déchets des décharges, mais promeuvent également les communautés de durabilité et de soutien. Ils montrent comment les petits changements peuvent faire une grande différence pour l'environnement et les gens.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Vous pouvez vous impliquer en essayant vous-même l'une de ces idées de recyclage, en soutenant les entreprises qui se concentrent sur l'upcycling ou la propagation du mot sur ce mouvement positif. Tous les efforts comptent!

**à emporter à une phrase**
Transformer les vieilles choses en nouveaux trésors est un moyen amusant et percutant d'aider notre planète et d'inspirer les autres.
articles.personality_title_es: 7 formas creativas de convertir artículos viejos en algo maravilloso
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Muchas personas en todo el mundo están trabajando duro para reducir el desperdicio y proteger nuestro planeta. El reciclaje es una forma de hacer esto: significa tomar cosas viejas o no utilizadas y transformarlas en artículos nuevos, útiles o hermosos.

**Qué pasó**
Se ha compartido una reciente colección de siete ideas de reciclaje brillante para inspirar a todos. Por ejemplo, Sea Bags ha convertido más de 500 toneladas de viejas velas en elegantes decoraciones estacionales, lo que demuestra que lo que una vez fue basura puede convertirse en tesoro.

**Impacto**
Estos proyectos creativos no solo mantienen toneladas de desechos fuera de los vertederos, sino que también promueven la sostenibilidad y las comunidades de apoyo. Muestran cómo los pequeños cambios pueden marcar una gran diferencia para el medio ambiente y las personas por igual.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Puede involucrarse probando una de estas ideas de reciclaje usted mismo, apoyando a las empresas que se centran en el reciclaje o difundiendo la palabra sobre este movimiento positivo. ¡Cada esfuerzo cuenta!

**Control de una oración**
Convertir cosas viejas en nuevos tesoros es una forma divertida e impactante de ayudar a nuestro planeta e inspirar a los demás.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of seven handcrafted objects—colorful sailcloth tote bags, decorated juice box seed starters with sprouting plants, denim insulation panels, a creatively folded pizza box turned into plates, a homemade makeup container, a sleek HDTV antenna made from cable parts, and a cozy furnished room silhouette—arranged in a harmonious circle on a soft neutral background, using natural muted blues, greens, browns, and creams, symbolizing creative upcycling and sustainable transformation.

articles.title: Unique 1.5m year-old ice to be melted to unlock mystery
articles.summary: BBC News went inside -23C freezers to see the ice that could "revolutionise" our knowledge of climate change.
articles.content:
Unique 1.5m year-old ice to be melted to unlock mystery

6 hours ago Share Save Georgina Rannard Climate and science correspondent Reporting from British Antarctic Survey, Cambridge Share Save

PNRA/IPEV The end of the ice cores are a 1.5 million year or even older time capsule

An ice core that may be older than 1.5 million years has arrived in the UK where scientists will melt it to unlock vital information about Earth's climate. The glassy cylinder is the planet's oldest ice and was drilled from deep inside the Antarctic ice sheet. Frozen inside is thousands of years of new information that scientists say could "revolutionise" what we know about climate change. BBC News went inside the -23C freezer room at the British Antarctic Survey in Cambridge to see the precious boxes of ice.

PNRA/IPEV The cores were stored in an ice cave Antarctica before being loaded onto a boat for Europe

"This is a completely unknown period of our Earth's history," says Dr Liz Thomas, head of ice core research at the British Antarctic Survey. Red warning lights flash above the door, and inside there is an emergency escape hatch into a tunnel in case something went wrong. The rules say we could only go inside for 15 minutes at a time, wearing padded overalls, boots, hats and gloves. Our camera's electronic shutter froze shut and our hair started to crackle as it turned icy. On a worktop next to stacked boxes of ice, Dr Thomas points out the oldest cores that could be 1.5 million years old. They shine and are so clear we can see our hands through them.

BBC News Dr Liz Thomas will lead a team analysing the ice cores at British Antarctic Survey

For seven weeks, the team will slowly melt the hard-won ice, releasing ancient dust, volcanic ash, and even tiny marine algae called diatoms that were locked inside when water turned to ice. These materials can tell scientists about wind patterns, temperature, and sea levels more than a million years ago. Tubes will feed the liquid into machines in a lab next door that is one of the only places in the world that can do this science.

BBC News The boxes of ice in Cambridge will be slowly melted over seven weeks

It was a huge multinational effort to extract the ice cores in Antarctica, at a cost of millions. The ice was chopped into 1m blocks and transported by boat and then in a cold van to Cambridge. Engineer James Veal helped to extract the ice close to the Concordia base in eastern Antarctica. "To hold that in my carefully gloved hands and be very careful not to drop the sections - it was an amazing feeling," he says.

PNRA/IPEV 2.8km of ice was extracted - more than eight Eiffel Towers stacked end-to-end

Two institutions in Germany and Switzerland also have received cross-sections of the 2.8km core. The teams could find evidence of a period of time more than 800,000 years ago when carbon dioxide concentrations may have been naturally as high or even higher than they are now, according to Dr Thomas. This could help them understand what will happen in our future as our planet responds to warming gases trapped in our atmosphere.

PNRA/IPEV The drilling took place about 40km from the Italian-French research station Concordia

"Our climate system has been through so many different changes that we really need to be able to go back in time to understand these different processes and different tipping points," she says. The difference between today and previous eras with high greenhouse gases is that now humans have caused the rapid rise in warming gases in the last 150 years. That is taking us into unchartered territory, but the scientists hope that the record of our planet's environmental history locked in the ice could give us some guidance.

The team will identify chemical isotopes in the liquid that could tell us the wind patterns, temperatures, and rainfall for a period of time between 800,000 and up to 1.5 million years ago or possibly more. They will use an instrument called an inductively couple plasma mass spectrometer (ICPMS) to measure over 20 elements and trace metals. That includes rare earth elements, sea salts and marine elements, as well as indicators of past volcanic eruptions. The work will help scientists understand a mysterious change called the Mid-Pleistocene Transition 800,000 to 1.2 million years ago when the planet's glacial cycles suddenly changed.

BBC News James Veale was part of the team in Antarctica that drilled and extracted the ice over four seasons
articles.reasoning: This news story highlights a significant scientific breakthrough in climate research, involving the study of ancient ice cores that could revolutionize our understanding of Earth's climate history and inform future climate action. It reflects international cooperation and advanced technology used for environmental progress.
articles.personality_title: Scientists to unlock climate secrets from 1.5 million-year-old ice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Deep inside freezers kept at a chilling -23°C, scientists have stored a precious piece of Earth’s history: a 1.5 million-year-old ice core. This ice is the oldest ever found and holds clues to how our planet’s climate has changed over an incredibly long time.

**What happened**
Recently, this rare ice core arrived in the UK from Antarctica, where it was carefully drilled and transported. Experts are now preparing to melt the ice slowly so they can study the tiny air bubbles trapped inside. These bubbles are like time capsules, preserving ancient air and helping scientists understand past climates.

**Impact**
By studying this ancient ice, researchers hope to fill big gaps in our knowledge about Earth’s climate history. This could help us better predict future climate changes and guide global efforts to protect our planet. The project also shows how countries work together using cutting-edge technology for the sake of our environment.

**What's next step**
The next step is the careful melting and analysis of the ice samples. Scientists will examine the trapped gases and particles to unlock the secrets held within. This process will take time but promises to offer valuable insights into Earth’s ancient atmosphere and climate cycles.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Unlocking the secrets of 1.5 million-year-old ice could revolutionize our understanding of climate change and help shape a healthier future for the planet.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques pour débloquer les secrets climatiques de la glace de 1,5 million de millions
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Au fond des congélateurs, maintenue à -23 ° C effrayante, les scientifiques ont stocké un précieux morceau de l'histoire de la Terre: un noyau de glace de 1,5 million de dollars. Cette glace est la plus ancienne jamais trouvée et contient des indices sur la façon dont le climat de notre planète a changé sur une période incroyablement longue.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Récemment, ce noyau de glace rare est arrivé au Royaume-Uni en provenance d'Antarctique, où il a été soigneusement percé et transporté. Les experts se préparent maintenant à faire fondre la glace lentement afin qu'ils puissent étudier les minuscules bulles d'air piégées à l'intérieur. Ces bulles sont comme des capsules temporelles, la préservation de l'air ancien et aident les scientifiques à comprendre les climats passés.

**Impact**
En étudiant cette glace ancienne, les chercheurs espèrent combler de grandes lacunes dans nos connaissances sur l'histoire du climat de la Terre. Cela pourrait nous aider à mieux prédire les changements climatiques futurs et guider les efforts mondiaux pour protéger notre planète. Le projet montre également comment les pays travaillent ensemble en utilisant une technologie de pointe pour notre environnement.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'étape suivante est la fusion et l'analyse soigneuses des échantillons de glace. Les scientifiques examineront les gaz et les particules piégés pour déverrouiller les secrets détenus à l'intérieur. Ce processus prendra du temps, mais promet d'offrir des informations précieuses sur l'atmosphère ancienne et les cycles climatiques de la Terre.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Le déverrouillage des secrets de la glace de 1,5 million de millions de personnes pourrait révolutionner notre compréhension du changement climatique et aider à façonner un avenir plus sain pour la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos desbloquear secretos climáticos de hielo de 1,5 millones de años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
En el fondo de los congeladores se mantuvieron en un escalofriante -23 ° C, los científicos han almacenado una preciosa pieza de la historia de la Tierra: un núcleo de hielo de 1,5 millones de años. Este hielo es el más antiguo jamás encontrado y tiene pistas sobre cómo el clima de nuestro planeta ha cambiado durante mucho tiempo.

**Qué pasó**
Recientemente, este raro núcleo de hielo llegó al Reino Unido desde la Antártida, donde fue cuidadosamente perforado y transportado. Los expertos ahora se están preparando para derretir el hielo lentamente para que puedan estudiar las pequeñas burbujas de aire atrapadas por dentro. Estas burbujas son como cápsulas de tiempo, preservando el aire antiguo y ayudando a los científicos a comprender los climas pasados.

**Impacto**
Al estudiar este antiguo hielo, los investigadores esperan llenar grandes vacíos en nuestro conocimiento sobre la historia climática de la Tierra. Esto podría ayudarnos a predecir mejor los cambios climáticos futuros y guiar los esfuerzos globales para proteger nuestro planeta. El proyecto también muestra cómo los países trabajan juntos utilizando tecnología de vanguardia por el bien de nuestro entorno.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
El siguiente paso es la cuidadosa fusión y el análisis de las muestras de hielo. Los científicos examinarán los gases y partículas atrapados para desbloquear los secretos mantenidos dentro. Este proceso llevará tiempo, pero promete ofrecer ideas valiosas sobre la atmósfera y los ciclos climáticos de la Tierra.

**Control de una oración**
Desbloquear los secretos del hielo de 1,5 millones de años podría revolucionar nuestra comprensión del cambio climático y ayudar a dar forma a un futuro más saludable para el planeta.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a large, translucent ice core cylinder glowing softly inside a cozy, softly lit scientific lab space, surrounded by delicate swirling representations of ancient dust, volcanic ash, and tiny marine algae, with a symbolic cold Antarctic landscape visible through a frosted window in the background.

articles.title: These dogs are trained to sniff out an invasive insect—and they're shockingly good at it
articles.summary: Dogs trained by everyday pet owners are proving to be surprisingly powerful allies in the fight against the invasive spotted lanternfly. In a groundbreaking study, citizen scientists taught their dogs to sniff out the pests’ hard-to-spot egg masses with impressive accuracy. The initiative not only taps into the huge community of recreational scent-detection dog enthusiasts, but also opens a promising new front in protecting agriculture. And it doesn’t stop there—these canine teams are now sniffing out vineyard diseases too, hinting at a whole new future of four-legged fieldwork.
articles.content:
Imagine if your dog's favorite game -- sniffing out treats or toys -- could help protect America's vineyards, orchards, and forests from a devastating invader.

It turns out, it just might.

A new study led by Virginia Tech found that volunteer dog-handler teams -- made up of everyday people and their pets -- can effectively detect the elusive egg masses of the spotted lanternfly, an invasive insect that's damaging farms and forests across the eastern and central United States.

It's the first study to show that citizen dog-handler teams can achieve detection success rates comparable to professional conservation detection dogs.

"These teams demonstrated that citizen scientists and their dogs can play a meaningful role in protecting agriculture and the environment from invasive species," said Sally Dickinson, the study's lead author, who recently earned her Ph.D. from Virginia Tech's College of Agriculture and Life Sciences. "With proper training, dog owners can turn their pets into powerful partners for conservation."

An invasive pest, a hidden target

The spotted lanternfly, native to Asia, was first detected in Pennsylvania in 2014. Since then, it's spread rapidly to 18 states, laying its eggs on trees, stone, lumber, and even cars and trailers, where it can hitch a ride to a new home.

Catching the bug early is key -- but finding its egg masses is no easy task.

"They often resemble mud smears or lichens and are tucked into bark crevices, cracks, or hidden undersides," said Mizuho Nita, a plant pathologist at Virginia Tech's Alson H. Smith Jr. Agricultural Research and Extension Center, who co-authored the study. "Finding them is like searching for a needle in a haystack."

That's where the dogs come in.

With a sense of smell that's tens of thousands of times more acute than humans', dogs can be trained to sniff out spotted lanternfly egg masses without disturbing the environment. Previous research has shown that professional conservation detection dogs can do this with high accuracy. But professional dogs are expensive, and there aren't nearly enough of them to cover the growing threat.

So the researchers asked: "What if we tapped into the tens of thousands of dog owners already doing scent detection as a hobby around the country?" Known as recreational scent work, this sport allows dogs to find hidden scents for fun in homes, parks, and training classes.

Dogs of all shapes, sizes, and snouts

Over 1,000 dog owners expressed interest in the study. More than 40 percent had prior experience in sport scent detection or related activities. Ultimately, 182 teams from across the U.S. were selected and given devitalized - or non-hatching - egg masses as training aids. Participants trained their dogs at home or in small groups, with oversight from a designated local trainer.

After several months of training, the dogs were put to the test in two environments - one indoor and one outdoor. In the controlled indoor environment, dogs had to complete an odor recognition test, identifying the box with the spotted lanternfly egg mass from among multiple boxes with other items and scents. Those that passed the odor recognition test advanced to a field test, where they had to find the scent in an outdoor environment with competing smells.

The results? Dogs correctly identified the egg masses 82 percent of the time in the controlled tests. In real-world field trials, accuracy dropped to 61 percent -- still better than many human searches. Of the dogs that passed both tests, 92 percent were successful in finding live egg masses with minimal extra training.

Study participant Bill Wellborn of Roanoke said his 7-year-old Tibetan terrier, Pepe, enjoyed the challenge. Over the course of six months, they trained with devitalized spotted lanternfly egg masses two or three times a week for 15 to 30 minutes.

"Anytime you can stimulate your dog, it's good for them," Wellborn said. "Pepe obviously enjoys it. And it's a way we can take dog skills and training to help our community."

Katie Thomas of Radford and her pit bull mix, Finch, also volunteered for the study, hoping to put their seven years of recreational scent work to real-world use.

"Being able to do the same thing for the greater good -- for citizen science -- adds another layer we didn't have before," she said.

Agriculture's new best friend?

Erica Feuerbacher, an animal behaviorist and Dickinson's graduate advisor and co-author, said the findings show the untapped power of community science.

"There are thousands of people out there doing scent work with their dogs just for fun," said Feuerbacher, associate professor in the School of Animal Sciences. "What Sally's study shows is that this can be more than a hobby -- these citizen-scientists and their dogs can be a valuable resource for fighting the spread of an invasive pest."

Sniffing out the spotted lanternfly may be just the beginning. A separate study co-authored by Nita, Dickinson, and Feuerbacher with researchers from Texas Tech University found that trained pet dogs could also detect powdery mildew, a major fungal disease of grapes and vineyards, with over 90 percent accuracy.

Together, these studies point to a growing role for dogs -- and their owners -- in safeguarding agriculture.

For Dickinson, a longtime firefighter and career search-and-rescue canine handler, the project reflects a personal mission: giving more dogs and their humans a chance to do meaningful work.

"This research is about more than detection," she said. "It's about empowering people to work alongside their dogs to protect the places and communities they care about."

About the research

The project was supported by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Institute of Food and Agriculture through the Agriculture and Food Research Initiative's Tactical Sciences for Agricultural Biosecurity program.

The research team included Dickinson, Feuerbacher, and Nita from Virginia Tech and Edgar Aviles-Rosa and Nathan Hall from Texas Tech University.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive scientific and community-driven effort to combat an invasive species threatening agriculture and ecosystems. It showcases citizen science, innovative use of dogs in conservation, and potential broader applications, all of which contribute to environmental protection and community engagement.
articles.personality_title: Dogs lend their noses to fight invasive insect with surprising skill
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The spotted lanternfly is a harmful insect causing damage to farms and forests in many parts of the United States. Finding its hidden egg masses is very tricky, making it hard to stop this invasive pest from spreading.

**What happened**
A new study from Virginia Tech showed that everyday pet owners trained their dogs to sniff out these sneaky egg clusters. These volunteer teams of dogs and handlers proved to be impressively good at spotting the insects’ eggs where humans often miss them.

**Impact**
This clever approach taps into the natural abilities of dogs and the enthusiasm of pet owners, creating a powerful new way to protect crops and natural areas. It also opens doors to using dogs to detect other plant problems, like diseases in vineyards.

**What's next step**
Researchers and citizen scientists plan to expand this program, training more dogs and exploring new ways these four-legged helpers can support farmers and conservation efforts across the country.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Everyday dogs and their owners are becoming unexpected heroes in the fight to protect America’s agriculture and forests from invasive pests.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les chiens prêtent leur nez pour combattre les insectes invasifs avec une compétence surprenante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
La lanterne tachetée est un insecte nocif causant des dommages aux fermes et aux forêts dans de nombreuses régions des États-Unis. Trouver ses masses d'oeufs cachées est très délicat, ce qui rend difficile l'empêcheur de ce ravageur invasif de se propager.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une nouvelle étude de Virginia Tech a montré que les propriétaires d'animaux de jour ont formé leurs chiens à renifler ces grappes d'œufs sournoises. Ces équipes bénévoles de chiens et de gestionnaires se sont avérées impressionnantes pour repérer les œufs des insectes où les humains les manquent souvent.

**Impact**
Cette approche intelligente exploite les capacités naturelles des chiens et l'enthousiasme des propriétaires d'animaux, créant une nouvelle façon puissante de protéger les cultures et les zones naturelles. Il ouvre également des portes à l'utilisation de chiens pour détecter d'autres problèmes de plantes, comme les maladies dans les vignobles.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs et les citoyens scientifiques prévoient d'étendre ce programme, de former plus de chiens et d'explorer de nouvelles façons de ces aides à quatre pattes peuvent aider les agriculteurs et les efforts de conservation à travers le pays.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Les chiens de tous les jours et leurs propriétaires deviennent des héros inattendus dans le combat pour protéger l'agriculture et les forêts américaines des ravageurs invasifs.
articles.personality_title_es: Los perros prestan sus narices para luchar contra el insecto invasivo con una habilidad sorprendente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
La linterna manchada es un insecto dañino que causa daños a las granjas y los bosques en muchas partes de los Estados Unidos. Encontrar sus masas de huevo ocultas es muy complicado, lo que hace que sea difícil evitar que esta plaga invasiva se extienda.

**Qué pasó**
Un nuevo estudio de Virginia Tech mostró que los dueños de mascotas de todos los días entrenaban a sus perros para oler estos racimos de huevos astutos. Estos equipos voluntarios de perros y manejadores demostraron ser impresionantemente buenos para detectar los huevos de los insectos donde los humanos a menudo los extrañan.

**Impacto**
Este enfoque inteligente aprovecha las habilidades naturales de los perros y el entusiasmo de los dueños de mascotas, creando una nueva forma poderosa de proteger los cultivos y las áreas naturales. También abre puertas para usar perros para detectar otros problemas de plantas, como enfermedades en los viñedos.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Investigadores y científicos ciudadanos planean expandir este programa, capacitar a más perros y explorar nuevas formas en que estos ayudantes de cuatro patas pueden apoyar a los agricultores y los esfuerzos de conservación en todo el país.

**Control de una oración**
Los perros cotidianos y sus dueños se están convirtiendo en héroes inesperados en la lucha para proteger la agricultura y los bosques de Estados Unidos de las plagas invasivas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a joyful dog with a keen nose sniffing a cluster of stylized spotted lanternfly egg masses delicately nestled in bark crevices, set against a softly glowing vineyard and orchard landscape in natural earthy tones, with subtle silhouettes of people nearby symbolizing citizen scientists and teamwork.

articles.title: Can AI help protect nature?
articles.summary: Despite risks, AI has ‘enormous potential’ for good, a Conservation International expert says.
articles.content:
In her own words, Ali Swanson is a “tech skeptic.”

This may seem odd, given Swanson’s role as Conservation International’s director of nature tech and innovation. But Swanson rarely uses words like “transformational” or “revolutionary” to describe artificial intelligence (AI), the broad term for emerging technology that can mimic human cognitive abilities. She has yet to catch the AI-will-kill-us-all fever, nor does she think AI is humanity’s salvation.

Still, Swanson, an ecologist by background, says she believes that AI can help conservationists dramatically increase the scale and speed of their work. And she spends her time and brainpower exploring ways to make that happen.

Conservation News spoke with Swanson to unpack the perils and promise of integrating AI with conservation.

Conservation News: What problems can artificial intelligence solve for conservation?

Ali Swanson: I think there are three key opportunities. First, this technology can help us understand the world faster and at greater scales. We’ll be able to map and monitor changes and threats with far greater precision and speed.

Second, AI can help us both optimize — and future-proof — our decisions. A lot of conservation is about maximizing our impact with limited resources and information. Broadening the scope of information will help increase certainty, which is something funders covet. AI lets us not only consider so many more variables in our calculations but also predict what might happen in the future — so we can make the best decisions today that last for generations to come.

And then the third piece, and this is something I'm really excited about, is thinking about how we can help democratize conservation action — putting our science into the hands of the people who can put it into practice.

Tell me more about that.

AS: Let’s take nature credits. There are dozens of different ‘nature credit’ methodologies out there, and they're all over the map on what they ask you to measure and report on — even the goals.

Imagine you could take all those frameworks, all the ecological data that's ever been collected for a place that you're working in, and all the global data sets that are out there — and throw them into AI. Then, you could ask it, in simple language, ‘Hey, I’m trying to get a nature credit in Yaguas National Park in Peru. What framework do I use? What biodiversity do I monitor to get that credit? How much will all this cost me?’ We are partnering with AI developers to build AI tools to help teams navigate these very questions — and testing the answers in CI’s nature credit pilots.

Right now, the conservation movement struggles to make informed decisions quickly. And it's not unique to nature credits; this is relevant to any kind of financing mechanism. This technology can push the bounds of what's possible in that respect. And I think it's the kind of thing that is achievable within the next ten years.

So far, we’ve discussed hypotheticals. Where is Conservation International already embedding AI into its programs, and what have we learned?

AS: Historically, we’ve used machine learning or deep learning to process large volumes of data much faster — like camera trap images in the Wildlife Insights program, or satellite data in our Climate Smart Shrimp program.

But we’re looking to dramatically increase the sustainability and accessibility of AI tools. We have an incredible opportunity with funding from the Patrick J. McGovern Foundation to pursue AI innovation. With this support, we are building out a dedicated AI curriculum at CI to upskill our staff and empower them to use AI strategically and responsibly. We are also partnering with AI developers to prototype AI agents that can help stakeholders make better conservation decisions, such as with nature credits or restoration.

We’re still figuring out what works and what doesn’t. At the same time, while I think AI holds enormous potential to help us do our work better and faster, we need to recognize it's not a panacea. As with any technology, it will create more challenges and problems to solve.

 

One of those challenges is AI’s massive environmental footprint. The average American datacenter uses roughly 17,000 showers’ worth of water each day, for example. How do you think about the tradeoff of potential long-term progress at a real short-term environmental cost?

AS: There’s no easy answer here, but I think the first step is visibility. Just over the state line from my house sit two coal-fired power plants that feed data centers. It makes visible for me a cost that is otherwise invisible just sitting at a computer prompting a chatbot.

In the big picture, I do think the benefit of doing our work faster, bigger and better will outweigh the costs of our AI use, in part because we're leveraging a tool that has largely been built and developed already.

But at Conservation International, we have a unique opportunity — and therefore, a responsibility — to bring different actors to the table, including major tech partners, other NGOs and world leaders to have this discussion. How can we, as a conservation sector, harness this tool for good, recognizing the costs that it creates? It’s one of the most important questions of our generation.

You’re an ecologist, but you now work on technology. How did that happen?

AS: I very much stumbled into this world of technology as a graduate student, studying how large carnivores co-exist in East Africa. The tools and methods that I needed to answer questions I was asking about lions, hyenas, cheetahs and wild dogs simply didn't exist. There was this clear need.

So, I partnered with technology developers to build the tools and approaches to collect data, interpret it and turn it into actionable scientific knowledge.

And now at Conservation International, I work across the organization to help our teams access the tools and technologies that they need to advance their work on the ground.

Max Marcovitch is a senior writer at Conservation International. Want to read more stories like this? Sign up for email updates. Also, please consider supporting our critical work.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the promising potential of AI technology to significantly aid conservation efforts, helping protect nature more effectively and efficiently. It acknowledges challenges but focuses on innovation, collaboration, and responsible use of technology for environmental progress.
articles.personality_title: Can AI be a new friend to nature?
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Ali Swanson, an ecologist and director at Conservation International, is cautious about technology. Though she doesn’t get swept up in hype about artificial intelligence, she sees real promise in it for protecting our planet.

**What happened**
Swanson shared her thoughts on how AI, which can think in ways similar to humans, might help conservation work. She acknowledges the concerns around AI but believes its smart use can boost efforts to care for nature.

**Impact**
By using AI thoughtfully, conservationists can better track endangered species, monitor forests, and fight illegal activities harming the environment. This technology has the potential to make protecting nature faster and more effective than before.

**What's next step**
The focus now is on innovation and teamwork. Experts like Swanson encourage combining AI with human knowledge, making sure the technology is used responsibly, and exploring new ways it can support environmental goals.

**One-sentence takeaway**
With careful use and collaboration, AI could become a powerful tool in the fight to protect our natural world.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'IA peut-elle être un nouvel ami de la nature?
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Ali Swanson, écologiste et directeur de Conservation International, est prudent quant à la technologie. Bien qu'elle ne soit pas balayée dans le battage médiatique sur l'intelligence artificielle, elle y voit une vraie promesse pour protéger notre planète.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Swanson a partagé ses réflexions sur la façon dont l'IA, qui peut penser d'une manière similaire aux humains, pourrait aider la conservation à travailler. Elle reconnaît les préoccupations concernant l'IA, mais pense que son utilisation intelligente peut stimuler les efforts pour s'occuper de la nature.

**Impact**
En utilisant de manière réfléchie de l'IA, les écologistes peuvent mieux suivre les espèces en voie de disparition, surveiller les forêts et lutter contre les activités illégales nuisant à l'environnement. Cette technologie a le potentiel de rendre la nature de protection plus rapide et plus efficace qu'auparavant.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'accent est maintenant mis sur l'innovation et le travail d'équipe. Des experts comme Swanson encouragent la combinaison de l'IA avec les connaissances humaines, en s'assurant que la technologie est utilisée de manière responsable et en explorant de nouvelles façons de soutenir les objectifs environnementaux.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Avec une utilisation minutieuse et une collaboration, l'IA pourrait devenir un outil puissant dans la lutte pour protéger notre monde naturel.
articles.personality_title_es: ¿Puede Ai ser un nuevo amigo para la naturaleza?
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Ali Swanson, ecologista y director de Conservation International, es cauteloso sobre la tecnología. Aunque no se ve afectada por la inteligencia artificial, ve una verdadera promesa para proteger nuestro planeta.

**Qué pasó**
Swanson compartió sus pensamientos sobre cómo la IA, que puede pensar de manera similar a los humanos, podría ayudar al trabajo de conservación. Ella reconoce las preocupaciones en torno a la IA, pero cree que su uso inteligente puede aumentar los esfuerzos para cuidar la naturaleza.

**Impacto**
Al usar AI cuidadosamente, los conservacionistas pueden rastrear mejor las especies en peligro de extinción, monitorear los bosques y combatir las actividades ilegales que dañan el medio ambiente. Esta tecnología tiene el potencial de hacer que la naturaleza de protección sea más rápida y efectiva que antes.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
El enfoque ahora está en la innovación y el trabajo en equipo. Expertos como Swanson fomentan la combinación de IA con conocimiento humano, se aseguran de que la tecnología se use de manera responsable y explore nuevas formas en que puede apoyar los objetivos ambientales.

**Control de una oración**
Con un uso cuidadoso y la colaboración, la IA podría convertirse en una herramienta poderosa en la lucha para proteger nuestro mundo natural.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a vibrant rainforest canopy seamlessly merging with a network of glowing, flowing data streams shaped like winding rivers, alongside stylized silhouettes of wild carnivores like lions and wild dogs watching attentively, symbolizing the harmony of AI technology and wildlife conservation working together to protect nature.

articles.title: How the world’s biggest bats got their enormous wingspans
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02228-zGenetic analysis helps to reveal why flying foxes can measure almost 2 metres from wingtip to wingtip.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses scientific analysis revealing why flying foxes have large wingspans, which contributes to understanding of wildlife biology and can support conservation efforts for these animals.
articles.personality_title: Uncovering the secret behind the world’s biggest bat wings
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Flying foxes, the largest bats on Earth, are famous for their impressive wingspans that can stretch nearly two meters from tip to tip. Understanding what gives these bats their extraordinary wings can help us appreciate these amazing creatures even more.

**What happened**
Scientists have used genetic analysis to discover the reasons behind the flying foxes’ enormous wingspans. By studying their DNA, researchers found specific genes that influence how their wings grow so large compared to other bats.

**Impact**
This discovery sheds light on the biology of flying foxes and brings us closer to understanding their unique adaptations. It also helps conservationists protect these important animals by giving them more knowledge about what makes flying foxes special and how they survive in the wild.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to continue exploring the genetics of flying foxes and other bat species. This could lead to even more insights about how animals develop unusual traits and support efforts to preserve their populations worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Genetic clues are helping us understand how flying foxes grew their giant wings, opening new doors for science and conservation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Découvrir le secret derrière les plus grandes ailes de chauve-souris du monde
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les renards volants, les plus grandes chauves-souris sur Terre, sont célèbres pour leurs impressionnants wingspans qui peuvent étirer près de deux mètres de la pointe à la pointe. Comprendre ce qui donne à ces chauves-souris leurs ailes extraordinaires peut nous aider à apprécier encore plus ces créatures incroyables.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les scientifiques ont utilisé une analyse génétique pour découvrir les raisons derrière les énormes ailes des Flying Foxes. En étudiant leur ADN, les chercheurs ont trouvé des gènes spécifiques qui influencent la façon dont leurs ailes deviennent si grandes par rapport aux autres chauves-souris.

**Impact**
Cette découverte met en lumière la biologie des renards volants et nous rapproche de la compréhension de leurs adaptations uniques. Il aide également les écologistes à protéger ces animaux importants en leur donnant plus de connaissances sur ce qui rend les renards volants spéciaux et comment ils survivent dans la nature.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de continuer à explorer la génétique des renards volants et d'autres espèces de chauves-souris. Cela pourrait conduire à encore plus d'informations sur la façon dont les animaux développent des traits inhabituels et soutiennent les efforts pour préserver leurs populations dans le monde entier.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Les indices génétiques nous aident à comprendre comment les renards volants ont augmenté leurs ailes géantes, ouvrant de nouvelles portes pour la science et la conservation.
articles.personality_title_es: Descubriendo el secreto detrás de las alas de murciélagos más grandes del mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los zorros voladores, los murciélagos más grandes de la Tierra, son famosos por sus impresionantes envergaduras que pueden estirar casi dos metros de punta a punta. Comprender lo que les da a estos murciélagos sus alas extraordinarias puede ayudarnos a apreciar aún más a estas increíbles criaturas.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos han utilizado el análisis genético para descubrir las razones detrás de las enormes enormes de los zorros voladores. Al estudiar su ADN, los investigadores encontraron genes específicos que influyen en cómo sus alas crecen tan grandes en comparación con otros murciélagos.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento arroja luz sobre la biología de los zorros voladores y nos acerca a comprender sus adaptaciones únicas. También ayuda a los conservacionistas a proteger a estos importantes animales al darles más conocimiento sobre lo que hace que los zorros voladores sean especiales y cómo sobreviven en la naturaleza.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los investigadores planean continuar explorando la genética de los zorros voladores y otras especies de murciélagos. Esto podría conducir a aún más ideas sobre cómo los animales desarrollan rasgos inusuales y apoyan los esfuerzos para preservar sus poblaciones en todo el mundo.

**Control de una oración**
Las pistas genéticas nos ayudan a comprender cómo los zorros voladores cultivaron sus alas gigantes, abriendo nuevas puertas para la ciencia y la conservación.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two enormous flying fox bats with gracefully extended, expansive wings, soaring gently over a softly lit twilight forest, their wings showcasing intricate natural patterns in soft browns and warm earth tones, symbolizing the majestic growth and evolution of the world’s largest bats.
